awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Trustworthy and Verifiable Software Backplane for the Cloud Edge
awd_abstract_narration:
Internet of things (IoT) produces a large influx of streaming data. The high cost and long latency in shipping raw IoT data necessitates edge processing. The objective of this project is to safeguard IoT data during edge processing. It seeks to establish a trusted data path on the edge. As the data flows through the path, the proposed edge system ensures 1) data confidentiality: IoT data is only accessible to trusted parties; 2) integrity: all the data having arrived at the edge is exactly manipulated according to the planned processing; 3) verifiability: data flows and computations on the edge are verifiable to a trusted cloud backend. 

The project's research thrusts will be tightly integrated with its education and outreach plan, educating students on trustworthy computing scenarios as well as stimulating the public's interests in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). There are plans to contribute fresh contents to curriculum; enhance student maker activities with in-situ IoT analytics; provide a summer course on IoT/Edge for local children; and, present relevant outreach at community IoT events. As IoT is revolutionizing modern society, the project aims toward more secure and efficient intelligence driven by IoT data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project targets new system software that safeguards edge systems, ensuring they process data efficiently, verifiably, and practically. Meanwhile, it integrates related educational activities into the research.

Through software and hardware research, the investigators have secured three key components at the edge: IO, storage, and compute. They have explored how to enable app code in Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs), such as Arm TrustZone, to safely access OS services and accelerators. In response to recent breakthroughs in generative AI, they have investigated the efficient execution of language models, speech models, and diffusion on the edge.

Project Outcomes: The project has produced the following new software concepts and designs:

  1. Novel designs of deception-based defense to stop information leaks when TEE software uses external OS services.
  2. Novel designs for hardening the trusted computing base for accelerators at the edge.
  3. New methods for synthesizing replay-based device drivers in TEE.
  4. Novel designs for executing language models on resource-constrained edge devices.
  5. Novel designs for executing deep speech understanding on edge devices.

The project has resulted in numerous publications and multiple open-source codebases, including GPUReplay, Driverlet, and SpeechCache.

Broader Impacts: The PI has recruited multiple research assistants through this project, thereby training the future workforce with security-oriented and efficiency-oriented programming expertise. The PI has engaged undergraduate RAs, many of whom are underrepresented minorities, through this project. The PI has incorporated the experience and software outcomes into both graduate-level and undergraduate-level OS curricula at the University of Virginia. The technologies developed are likely to impact how the industry constructs and analyzes edge software. The research conducted is also likely to raise public awareness of security concerns in client and edge deployments.
